abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and institutional development
            impacts were negligible, with both performances by the Bank
            and Borrower rated unsatisfactory. Lessons primarily convey
            that the project was an inappropriate vehicle to tackle the
            problems identified in the appraisal report, where major
            cross-sectoral reforms, and improvements needed in the
            private sector investment climate, could not be delivered by
            a project of this size, which was therefore doomed to fail.
            Likewise, physical constraints to evacuate produce to
            markets, and bring inputs to farms, were of such enormous
            proportions that they could not be adequately addressed by a
            single sectoral project, in spite of the redesigned project,
            which unsuccessfully tried to address this by refocusing on
            only certain key bottlenecks. Such factors convey the need
            to establish appropriate, and regularly updates to a clear
            project implementation plan early on, which would have
            helped the project unit focus its activities, and made
            supervision easier. The Government needs to clearly
            formulate, and implement a strategy that recognizes the
            importance of the private sector, and supports the creation
            of a favorable investment climate. No such strategy had been
            formulated, and as a result, few foreign investors are
            present, despite the relative advantage of Guinea in terms
            of availability of arable land and water, and proximity to
            major markets. The policy letter therefore became a tool
            that was only used by the Bank for its internal processing
            purposes. Moreover, a project seeking structural and
            institutional reforms, cannot be implemented by an
            independent project unit with only weak ties to Government;
            rather, Government has to be actively involved and lead the process.
